thread.title: Brazen thugs stab teen six times and attack him with belt - while filming themselves on mobile phone
thread.title_full: Brazen thugs stab teen six times and attack him with belt - while filming themselves on mobile phone

author: Steve Robson
title: Brazen thugs stab teen six times and attack him with belt - while filming themselves on mobile phone
text:
Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A teenager was stabbed six times and attacked with a belt in an appalling attack in a chicken shop caught on CCTV. 
Three thugs cornered the victim, aged 18, at the counter and launched a vicious assault. 
In shocking footage, one can be seen using a large belt to smack the victim around the head. 
Two others are both holding large knives during the assault which happened at 5.30pm on Monday at Dallas Chicken in Brixton, South London. CCTV footage of the Brixton stabbing (Photo: Metropolitan Police) 
One of the attackers can be seen using a mobile phone to film the ordeal. 
Police say the victim was stabbed four times in the leg, once in the abdomen and once in the arm - but survived. 
He was also kicked in the head while on the floor. 
Witnesses said there were a further three suspects on bikes outside the shop at the time. 
All fled the scene together following the attack. The victim was stabbed six times, hit with a belt and kicked in the head (Photo: Metropolitan Police) 
The victim was taken to hospital where he required an operation to the abdomen but was later discharged. 
He will require further surgery to his arm police said. 
Detective Constable Remy Smith, from Lambeth CID, said: "This is a shocking and brutal assault that has left the victim very distressed from his ordeal." The victim required an operation to his abdomen but survived (Photo: Metropolitan Police) 
"We are keen to identify the men in the CCTV footage so we can speak to them about the incident. 
"We would also urge anyone who witnessed the incident to contact us." 
One man has been arrested on suspicion of possession of a knife. Enquiries continue. 
Anyone with information or any witnesses are urged to call police via 101 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. Like us on Facebook
